results.title: Jealousy
results.brief_description: An absorbing program, hosted by psychologists Peter Quarry, in which people talk about their jealousy - how they felt, what they did and why. A private investigator, police and psychologists discuss how jealousy can lead to violence and present strategies for coping with it.

results.title: Je
results.creator_credit: Louis Portugais, Leonard Forest and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An experiment in modern creative dancing in which a mime of self discovery is expressed in body movements with accompanying sounds. As the movements express awakening, thought and feeling, the sounds change from sounds of nature to marching feet and atomic explosions. Dance: Suzanne Rivest. Camera: Francois Seguillon. Sound arrangement: Maurice Blackburn.

results.title: Jazzoo [Short version]
results.brief_description: Illustrates the beauty, colour and activities of a zoo in the early hours of a summer morning. This film illustrates how the filmmaker uses his basic resource - the visual image - without the use of words.

results.title: Jazzoo
results.creator_credit: John Camie and Tee Pee Productions
results.brief_description: Designed to capture the beauty, colour and activities of a zoo in the early hours of a summer morning, with striking visual images and a lively, original jazz score. Photographed at the St Louis Zoo, we watch the animals commence their day, and their encounters with the early spectators.

results.title: Jazz on a summer's day
results.brief_description: A classic film for lovers of jazz music, “Jazz On A Summer’s Day” documents the Newport Jazz Festival of 1958, which ranged from Anita O’Day’s sassy rendition of ‘Sweet Georgia Brown’ to the powerful spirituality of Mahalia Jackson’s great gospel singing. Director Bert Stern chose to not merely show the performers on stage, but to fuse the music with images of the festival as whole, giving a sense and feel of the whole event. Includes music performed by Louis Armstrong, Mahalia Jackson, Anita O’Day, Gerry Mulligan, Dina Washington, George Shearing, Chuck Berry and Thelonius Monk.

results.title: Jazz mania
results.creator_credit: Chris Hubbard and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: This production takes a look at the impact of Jazz on people and society when it was firstly introduced in the 1920’s. Incorporating archival footage with dramatised scenes resembling newsreels of the time, the film documents the shock and consternation registered by polite society.

results.title: Jazz jukebox: the Snader Telescriptions 1951-52
results.brief_description: This is an amazing collection of 17 rare, high quality, music clips from 1951-52 capturing some of the major artists of the day including Bob Crosby & the Bobcats (March of the Bobcats), Teresa Brewer (Music, music, music), Peggy Lee (What more can a woman do?), Nat King Cole (Little girl), Jack Teagarden & his Allstars (Jack Armstrong blues) and The Weavers (Goodnight Irene). The 3-minute clips were originally produced as television fillers by Snader Telescriptions but have since proven to be an invaluable and historical record of the pre rock’n’roll music scene of the fifties.

results.title: Jazz in the concert hall. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Roger Englander and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description: Leonard Bernstein explains and illustrates the nature of jazz and its fusion with serious concert music since the 1920’s. Includes three major works performed by the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and soloists to illustrate this fusion: Gunther Schuller’s “Journey into jazz” featuring jazz musicians Don Ellis (Itrumpet), Eric Dolphy (alto sax), Benny Golsen (tenor sax), Richard Davis (bass) and Joseph Cocuzzo (drums); Aaron Copland’s “Concerto for piano and orchestra”; Larry Austin’s “Improvisations for orchestra and jazz soloists”.

results.title: Jazz in exile
results.creator_credit: Chuck France and Francerelli Film Productions
results.brief_description: Filmclips of American jazz performances and interviews with musicians are used to discuss why America has failed to appreciate its most prominent, indigenous art form. Why have so many artists left and settled in Europe and why have some gone home in the last few years? Musicians featured: Dexter Gordon, Johnny Griffin, Steve Lacy, Randy Weston, Phil Woods, Art Farmer, Richard Davis, Gato Barberie, Carla Bley, Freddie Hubbard, Mal Waldron.
